misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the loop termination condition 'c == -1' acts as a continuous trigger that will stop the loop's execution the very instant the value of 'c' changes within the loop body.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java's execution model, the for-loop condition is only evaluated at the start of each iteration. Once an iteration begins, the entire block (and the update expression 'i++') will execute before the condition is checked again. The computer does not 'watch' variables for changes in real-time during the execution of a statement block.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: While this logic works here because the assignment is the final statement in the loop, this mental model typically leads to off-by-one errors or 'trailing execution' when more code follows the state change inside the loop.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the descriptive text in System.out.print (like 'Enter size') acts as a label or instruction that the computer uses to understand what type of data it is receiving or what the next variable represents.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, prompts and inputs are entirely decoupled. System.out.print sends characters to the output stream, while y.nextInt() pulls data from the input stream. The computer does not 'read' the prompt to determine the meaning of the input; it simply takes the next available integer.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the program should always provide a descriptive text prefix for its answers, even when the requirements might imply a raw value (like printing -1 when not found).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: While user-friendly, automated grading systems and strict problem specifications often distinguish between the value itself and the descriptive label. The student assumes the 'Found at index:' label is part of the required answer format even for error/negative cases.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that including 'c == -1' in the loop header acts as a continuous monitor or an 'interrupt'. They believe the loop will stop the exact moment the variable 'c' is assigned a value other than -1.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java notional machine, the loop condition is only evaluated at the start of each iteration. While the code works because the 'if' statement is the last operation in the loop, if there were more code after 'c = i', it would still execute and 'i' would still increment before the condition is checked again.
